labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Geofencing is a special case of a larger issue
issues.author: TheBankster
issues.body:
Data sovereignty is very important and this draft raises an important issue in Enterprise IT controls that needs to be addressed.

That said, geofencing of a workload is but a special case of being able to attest a host on which the workload is running to obtain claims about this host. Those claims might include statements about the device being fully patched per the owner’s policy, or be running a particular version of some software of interest.

What I believe we need to figure out is how to do that as an architectural building block, and then a geofencing claim would fall out of that more general architecture.

Also, perhaps I have missed this, but workload live migration between hosts is an important consideration to tackle as well, as geofencing claims can be very easily invalidated if the workload migrates between jurisdictions.

comments.author: ramkri123
comments.body: @nedmsmith - I have accepted all your comments. Please approve

```suggestion
* Geo-fence policies are of four flavours - (1) boolean membership of given boundary (rectangular, circular, state etc.), (2) precise location, (3) precise bounding box/circle of location, (4) approximate location with no definition of boundary.
The first one, boolean membership of given boundary, is the most common and will be assumed as the default. They are available in the form of pre-defined templates or can be configured on demand.
Enterprises, who are the user of the hosts, choose the geo-fence policies to be enforced for various hosts.
Note that the hosts must belong to the set of trusted hosts in a shared ledger.
The geo-fence policies applied to the set of trusted hosts are recorded in a shared ledger.
```

Note (1), (2), etc... won't render as numbered bullets. use:
"1. my first bullet"
"1. my second bullet"
"1. my third bullet"
without the quote marks.
Putting only one sentence per line makes it easier to review and suggest changes.

```suggestion
# Attestation for System Bootstrap and Agent Initialization
```
using slash character "/" in a title is hard to read

```suggestion
## Attestation of OS Integrity and Proof of Residency on Host
```

```suggestion
## Start/restart time attestation/remote verification of agent for integrity and proof of residency on Host
```

How is this section different from the previous section that is almost the same name?

```suggestion
* Server creates a SPIFFE ID along with the sha256sum of the TPM AK public key.
Server stores agent SPIFFE ID mapping to TPM AK public key in a shared datastore.
```
IETF markdown doesn't do mermaid.

reviews.author: copilot-pull-request-reviewer
reviews.body:
## Pull Request Overview

This PR cleans up the markdown document by refining heading levels, standardizing figure labels, and improving whitespace for readability.

- Converted key bullet items into proper markdown headers (`###`, `##`, etc.).
- Standardized figure link captions with a consistent prefix.
- Reorganized sections around SPIFFE/SPIRE architecture and end-to-end workflow with added blank lines.


<details>
<summary>Comments suppressed due to low confidence (1)</summary>

**draft-lkspa-wimse-verifiable-geo-fence.md:143**
* Fix the typo 'compmliance' to 'compliance'.
```
Enterprises handling of sensitive data relies on dedicated cloud hosts (e.g., EU sovereign cloud providers) that ensure compmliance to data residency laws, while also ensuring appropriate levels of service (e.g., high availability).
```
</details>

comments.body: [nitpick] Bold formatting inside an H3 header is redundant; consider removing the `**` markers and relying on the heading style alone.

[nitpick] Consider using sequential figure numbers (e.g., 'Figure 1:') instead of '--' to improve cross-references in the document.
```suggestion
[Figure 1: Cybersecure and Compliant Agentic AI Workflow](https://github.com/nedmsmith/draft-klspa-wimse-verifiable-geo-fence/blob/ramki-mod2/pictures/secure-agentic-workflow.svg/)
```

[nitpick] This main section appears under higher‐level headings; use `##` instead of `#` to keep a consistent hierarchy.
```suggestion
## SPIFFE/SPIRE Architecture modifications
```

[nitpick] Use `##` for this section header to maintain consistency with other level‐2 headings.
```suggestion
## End-to-End Workflow
```
LGTM

reviews.author: copilot-pull-request-reviewer
reviews.body:
## Pull Request Overview

Cleanup of sensor references and standardization of GNSS terminology in the verifiable geo-fence draft.

- Removed Wi-Fi sensor references from host description and geolocation components
- Updated table rows for Trusted OS and Geolocation Agent to replace Wi-Fi with GNSS and harmonize terminology


<details>
<summary>Comments suppressed due to low confidence (1)</summary>

**draft-lkspa-wimse-verifiable-geo-fence.md:186**
* Add a space after the markdown list dash (e.g., `- Host`) to ensure proper rendering of the bullet item.
```
-Host contains location devices like mobile sensor, GPS sensor, GNSS sensor, etc. Host is a compute node, including servers, routers, and end-user appliances like smartphones, tablets, or PCs.
```
</details>

comments.body:
Include "with" after "tamper" (e.g., "Does not tamper with GPS/GNSS location data") for correct grammar.
```suggestion
| Trusted OS | Trusted drivers for storage/location root of trust. Does not tamper with GPS location/GNSS location data. | |
| Geolocation Agent SW - OS level service | Trusted application. Does not tamper with GPS location/GNSS location data. Signs GPS/GNSS location data (latitude/longitude/altitude) using TPM attestation key. | Possibly a SPIRE-agent plug-in with TPM attestation. |
```

Include "with" after "tamper" (e.g., "Does not tamper with GPS/GNSS location data") for correct grammar.
```suggestion
| Geolocation Agent SW - OS level service | Trusted application. Does not tamper with GPS location/GNSS location data. Signs GPS/GNSS location data (latitude/longitude/altitude) using TPM attestation key. | Possibly a SPIRE-agent plug-in with TPM attestation. |
```

reviews.author: copilot-pull-request-reviewer
reviews.body:
## Pull Request Overview

This PR cleans up the draft by updating image paths to the main branch, removing Wi-Fi sensor references, and aligning terminology around geolocation data.

- Updated figure URLs to use the `main` branch instead of `ramki-mod2`
- Removed Wi-Fi sensor entries and standardized on GPS/GNSS in text and tables
- Adjusted table rows for Trusted OS and Geolocation Agent SW to reflect GPS/GNSS changes


<details>
<summary>Comments suppressed due to low confidence (3)</summary>

**draft-lkspa-wimse-verifiable-geo-fence.md:187**
* [nitpick] The term "mobile sensor" is ambiguous; consider specifying the exact sensor type (e.g., "mobile network sensor") to improve clarity.
```
Host contains location devices like mobile sensor, GPS sensor, GNSS sensor, etc. Host is a compute node, including servers, routers, and end-user appliances like smartphones, tablets, or PCs.
```
**draft-lkspa-wimse-verifiable-geo-fence.md:371**
* You removed the GNSS signal authentication note here. It provides valuable context on anti-spoofing measures; consider re-adding or relocating it.
```
**Note**: A GPS sensor with a cryptographic signature, also known as GNSS signal authentication, uses digital signatures in the broadcast signal to ensure the authenticity and integrity of the GPS data, protecting against spoofing attacks.
```
**draft-lkspa-wimse-verifiable-geo-fence.md:370**
* [nitpick] The comment about a SPIRE-agent plug-in implementation was removed; reintroducing it (or a similar note) could help readers understand integration options.
```
Possibly a SPIRE-agent plug-in with TPM attestation.
```
</details>

reviews.author: copilot-pull-request-reviewer
reviews.body:
## Pull Request Overview

This PR cleans up the verifiable geo-fence draft by updating asset references and refining the hardware/device descriptions.

- Updated figure URLs to point at the `main` branch instead of `ramki-mod2`
- Removed “Wi-Fi sensor” mentions from host device lists and hardware table
- Simplified table entries for trusted OS and geolocation agent


<details>
<summary>Comments suppressed due to low confidence (1)</summary>

**draft-lkspa-wimse-verifiable-geo-fence.md:187**
* After removing 'Wi-Fi sensor' from the host devices list, clarify whether Wi-Fi-based geolocation is no longer supported or intentionally omitted to prevent reader confusion.
```
Host contains location devices like mobile sensor, GPS sensor, GNSS sensor, etc. Host is a compute node, including servers, routers, and end-user appliances like smartphones, tablets, or PCs.
```
</details>

comments.body:
[nitpick] The table cell content is dense and mixes inline bullets and dashes; consider reformatting as a sub-list or separate bullet points for each root of trust option to improve clarity. ```suggestion | Trusted hardware devices (focus on geolocation) | Storage root of trust:
  • TPM
Location root of trust options:
  • GPS sensor
  • GNSS sensor - signal authentication prevents spoofing [galileo]
Mobile sensor:
  • modem
  • antenna
  • SIM - Mobile device location is obtained from mobile network operator and not from device
| | ```

[nitpick] Consider using 'and' instead of a slash in 'GPS/GNSS' (e.g., 'GPS and GNSS') for readability and consistency with surrounding text.
```suggestion
| Geolocation Agent SW - OS level service | Trusted application. Does not tamper GPS location and GNSS location data. Signs GPS and GNSS location data (latitude/longitude/altitude) using TPM attestation key. | |
```

reviews.author: copilot-pull-request-reviewer
reviews.body:
## Pull Request Overview

This PR introduces a prototype web application built with Flask and includes several supporting files. Key changes include:  
- Addition of a minimal Flask application in app.py with several routes.  
- Inclusion of requirements.txt specifying Flask==2.3.2.  
- Numerous virtual environment and distribution metadata files, as well as diagram backup files, are committed.

### Reviewed Changes

Copilot reviewed 1161 out of 1161 changed files in this pull request and generated no comments.

| File | Description |
| ---- | ----------- |
| prototype/app.py | Contains the main Flask application and its routing logic. |
| prototype/requirements.txt | Specifies the required Flask version. |
| prototype/venv/** | Added virtual environment distribution metadata files for various packages (annotated_types, MarkupSafe, Flask, etc.). |
| pictures/*.drawio.bkp | New backup diagram files related to internal design references. |

comments.body:
> I couldn't test that the python code was working as expected since there isn't any Makefile automation in the prototype directories. I assume it is working but can't verify. Does it make sense to have Makefiles in these for reviewers to easily check that it works?

Unfortunately, Makefile automation is not ready yet. We have follow the readme and manually try it out.

reviews.author: copilot-pull-request-reviewer
reviews.body:
## Pull Request Overview

A fully working TPM-backed geolocation attestation prototype with end-to-end key/cert generation, signing, verification, and updated extension integration.

- Introduce TPM (“tpm”) and intermediate (“x”) key/cert generation and signing in `win-app.py`
- Enhance `server.py` and `dpi-proxy.py` to verify full certificate chains, replace `/init_nonce` with `/get_access_token_with_initial_nonce`, and add CORS
- Update `background.js` to await the new nonce endpoint and integrate attestation token

### Reviewed Changes

Copilot reviewed 14 out of 14 changed files in this pull request and generated 2 comments.

<details>
<summary>Show a summary per file</summary>

| File                                    | Description                                                      |
|-----------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------|
| x_private_key.pem, x_cert.pem, tpm_*.pem | Prototype private keys and certificates (for local testing only) |
| win-app.py                              | Generate key hierarchy, create and sign certificates locally      |
| server.py                               | Certificate-chain verification, new nonce endpoint, CORS headers |
| dpi-proxy.py                            | Proxy handling for nonce, DPI marker, and chain verification      |
| background.js                           | Async nonce retrieval, header injection for new endpoint          |
| requirements.txt                        | Added `cryptography` and `reverse_geocode` dependencies           |
| README.md (and prototype README)        | Updated usage and replaced `/init_nonce` references               |
</details>



<details>
<summary>Comments suppressed due to low confidence (3)</summary>

**prototype-browser-extension-tpm/README.md:13**
* The README still refers to `/init_nonce`, but the code now provides `/get_access_token_with_initial_nonce`. Update the docs to match the actual endpoint.
```
- Provides an endpoint (`/init_nonce`) for nonce initialization.
```
**prototype-browser-extension-tpm/x_private_key.pem:1**
* Committing raw private keys in the repo is a security risk. Move these keys to a secure store or use environment-based injection and remove them from version control.
```
-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY-----
```
**prototype-browser-extension-tpm/background.js:186**
* Using `await` inside a non-async callback will cause a syntax error. Either mark the `onBeforeSendHeaders` listener as `async` or handle the promise via `.then()`.
```
    if (nonceReady) await nonceReady;
```
</details>

comments.body:
The `cert_chain_b64` parameter is never used; the function always loads a hardcoded chain. Either remove the unused parameter or use the passed-in chain for verification.
```suggestion
def verify_certificate_chain_and_signature(token, cert_chain_b64=None):
    # Load certificate chain dynamically if provided, otherwise use hardcoded chain
    if cert_chain_b64:
        try:
            cert_chain_pem = base64.b64decode(cert_chain_b64)
            cert_chain = x509.load_pem_x509_certificate(cert_chain_pem, default_backend())
        except Exception as e:
            app.logger.error(f"Error decoding or loading provided certificate chain: {e}")
            return False
    else:
        # Hardcoded certificate chain for dev/test (use real newlines, not \n)
        hardcoded_chain = b"""-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIICzTCCAbWgAwIBAgIUCO+pSNMjARQXT+GiAhHCIr5UgnQwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
BQAwHTEbMBkGA1UEAwwSVFBNVGVzdENlcnRpZmljYXRlMB4XDTI1MDYwOTA0NDMw
OFoXDTI2MDYwOTA0NDMwOFowJDEiMCAGA1UEAwwZR2VvTG9jYXRpb24gU2lnbmlu
ZyBLZXkgWDCCASIwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEBBQADggEPADCCAQoCggEBALUvzUqd/yDr
MMpFofcmbZEhh8DVzh7UDxZUgu8d5UArdV0cGBFIrb2+w9yhVPY3MVATKy3BXL+Q
jCBohycShQqvBJ8YuSrxSqfav2X8JL/78udQImevaT7d8dxDVtKL4YEGKJhK0CwG
Vzeqk1xU13RDCXOGA6Q8IyxsexyEvEM8zbYRaTJjTRxcuatoTvi0aMlvRqbzhc6K
wo4faR+KXK/DfdHy77yZnR/yd+sSAVDQ9f5r3QZO8ulq3se4umtr0Zvtv307X6QM
YC9W+pVEM1NqkXbWXD+ei3zQFEdIoTT1lUS8ZxI6S7PxbMGv0n3/9HnWmcUufoLW
zboCO8B3658CAwEAATANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsFAAOCAQEAcr0l60lgxlLJxzjm49Kd
```
[nitpick] Embedding a long hardcoded certificate chain hurts readability and maintainability. Consider loading PEM files from disk or configuration.

reviews.body: Approving, but with emphasis on getting the makefiles written to make it easier on reviewers.
